steps.title: Wait until your plant is at least 4 inches (10 cm) tall.
steps.content: Wait until your plant is at least 4 inches (10 cm) tall. Trimming the plant too early could cause your plant to fail to thrive, so be patient. Luckily, oregano usually grows quickly. [1] X Research source Pruning your oregano will encourage new growth. Not only will it grow more leaves, it'll even grow more stems!

steps.title: Cut back no more than 1/3rd of the plant at a time.
steps.content: Cut back no more than 1/3rd of the plant at a time. This prevents over-pruning. If you cut away too much of the plant at once, your plant may not survive. [2] X Research source Before pruning your oregano again, make sure it's grown back to at least 4 inches (10 cm) tall.

steps.title: Cut the stems when you need to remove several at once.
steps.content: Cut the stems when you need to remove several at once. Place a pair of scissors or small pruning shears against the stem above the leaves where you plan to make your cut. Then, make a clean cut to remove the stalk. [3] X Research source You may try to cut several stems at once, depending on the size of your plant. It's best if you cut just 1 stalk at a time.

steps.title: Pinch off the stems for easy pruning.
steps.content: Pinch off the stems for easy pruning. Pinching is a quick, easy way to prune your herbs. [4] X Research source Place your fingers on the stem just above the leaves, then use your fingernails to pinch off the stem. [5] X Research source It helps to hold the base of the stem with your other hand to avoid damaging the rest of the stalk. This is a great option for removing 1 or 2 stems at a time.

steps.title: Set the stalks aside while you continue pruning.
steps.content: Set the stalks aside while you continue pruning. If you plan to use them in your kitchen, you should place them in a clean, dry container. [6] X Research source Continue to cut until you've trimmed all of the stems you'd like to prune. If the removed stems are still green, you can use them in your kitchen! However, dead stems should be composted or thrown away.

steps.title: Deadhead the flowers after they fade at the end of summer.
steps.content: Deadhead the flowers after they fade at the end of summer. This allows the plant to direct its nutrients toward new growth instead of seeding. Using scissors or pruning shears, cut just below the flowers. You can also trim further down the stem, as long as you don't cut more than â…“ of the stalk. As an alternative, you can deadhead the flowers by simply pinching off the old flower. This works better if the flower is dead or dying. [7] X Trustworthy Source Royal Horticultural Society Leading gardening charity in the U.K. providing resources for identifying, growing and caring for flowers and other plants Go to source

steps.title: Stop pruning at least 2 weeks before cold weather is forecast.
steps.content: Stop pruning at least 2 weeks before cold weather is forecast. Your plant will be vulnerable during cold weather, so it's a good idea to stop pruning it before winter comes. This increases the likelihood that it will survive winter! [8] X Research source If you want to use your oregano during winter, it's best to rely on dried herbs that you've stored.

steps.title: Remove dead stems during the winter.
steps.content: Remove dead stems during the winter. Wait until late winter to prepare the oregano for regrowth in the spring. Look for stems that are dry, brown, and lack leaves. Trim them down to the base of the plant, just above the roots. [9] X Trustworthy Source Royal Horticultural Society Leading gardening charity in the U.K. providing resources for identifying, growing and caring for flowers and other plants Go to source You can use scissors or small pruning shears.

steps.title: Add an organic liquid fertilizer to the oregano.
steps.content: Add an organic liquid fertilizer to the oregano. This will provide it with extra nutrients to help it go into the next growing season. For best results, mix the fertilizer into water and pour it over the plant at its next watering. [10] X Trustworthy Source Royal Horticultural Society Leading gardening charity in the U.K. providing resources for identifying, growing and caring for flowers and other plants Go to source Be sure to follow the label to ensure that you provide the right amount of fertilizer. You can find a liquid fertilizer at your local gardening store or online.

steps.title: Harvest
steps.content: Harvest oregano just before the plant flowers, or as needed. Oregano is most flavorful right before the plant flowers, so this is the perfect time to harvest if you plan to dry or freeze your herbs. However, you can also harvest small amounts of oregano to use fresh in your kitchen. [11] X Research source Keep in mind that the oregano may taste bitter after the plant flowers, so it's a good idea to harvest the remaining stems before your plant flowers. You can dry them by hanging them in bunches or using a dehydrator. Alternatively, you could freeze them. The best time to harvest oregano is in the morning after the dew dries. The flavor of your oregano will be strongest during warm weather.

steps.title: Place your scissors 1/3rd of the way down a stem of oregano.
steps.content: Place your scissors 1/3rd of the way down a stem of oregano. You can harvest less, but not more. Position the scissors against the stem in a spot that's in between the leaves to prevent damaging the leaves. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Run your fingers along the stem to remove just the leaves if you prefer.
steps.content: Run your fingers along the stem to remove just the leaves if you prefer. Place your thumb and middle finger just below the leaves you want to harvest. Slowly run your hand up the stem to pull off the leaves, collecting them as you go. Place the leaves in a clean, dry container for use in your kitchen. Cut away the bare stem using your scissors. [13] X Research source This is a great alternative for days when you just want a few leaves to season a dish.
